A white supremacist has been sentenced to death for killing nine black worshippers in a church in South Carolina in a racially motivated attack. 
Dylann Roof was found guilty of federal hate crimes. 
He declined to plead for his life in front of jurors by saying: "I still feel like I had to do it." 
Jurors also convicted the 22-year-old guilty of obstructing the exercise of religion for those he shot after sitting with them in a Bible study. 
Roof stood with his hands at his side and his face emotionless, as a clerk read the verdict aloud in court. 
The court had heard he carried out the attack at the historic Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church wanting in June last year to ignite a war between the races. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Dylann Roof LAUGHS as he confesses to shooting Share this video Watch Next CCTV of Dylann Roof leaving Charleston church with gun 
This is the chilling moment Dylann Roof LAUGHED during a police interview as he confessed to shooting dead nine black Charleston churchgoers. 
The 22-year-old white supremacist - whose lawyers are not disputing the evidence - can be seen chuckling to himself during the video recording played in court yesterday, 
As investigators questioned him over the mass killings at Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church - he can be heard to admit: "Uh, I did it..." 
Then, after Roof waived his rights, they pressed him further - asking him exactly what he had done? Dylann Roof (Photo: Splash) 
He paused for around 30 seconds before replying bluntly: "I killed them." 
Roof could be heard chuckling as he continued: "Well, I killed them I guess." 
More then 60 bullets were sprayed around the interior of the building of the church, claiming the lives of a congregation with whom Roof had sat for the preceding bible study group on June 17 last year. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now CCTV of Dylann Roof leaving Charleston church with gun Share this video Watch Next 
Prosecutors are seeking the death penalty. 
When questioned the next day a detective begins: "Can you tell us about what happened last night?" 
Roof sounds almost spaced out as he replies: "Uhhhh... woo-hah... yeah... 
"I mean, I just... I went to that church in Charleston and, er... you know, I er... I did it." 
The investigator asks him: "Did what? 
Roof simply laughs at the question: "Ha!" 
The investigator continues: "I know it's tough sometimes to say it..." 
Roof explains: "Well I, it's not that i don't want to say because I don't want to make myself seem guilty, I just don't like really saying it..." 
The investigator replies: "Sometimes we have to face those those things, the realities..." 
His colleague then explains to Roof: "We don't want to put words in your mouth, which is why we are asking what you did do." 
Roof continues: "Well, i did it. I killed them, i guess. I i don't really know how many people and that..." (Photo: Getty) 
The investigator asks: "So did you shoot them?" 
Roof replies: "Yes" 
The detective asks: "What kind of gun did you use?" 
Roof laughs at the question, replying: "A Glock 45." 
The investigator asks: "So you pulled out the gun - started shooting people, how?" 
Roof replies: "Yeah that's it." Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now CCTV of Dylann Roof leaving Charleston church with gun Share this video Watch Next 
Earlier in the court proceedings a video showing the moment Dylann Roof was seen leaving the church in South Carolina was played. 
The jury were shown 20 video clips on the second day of Roof's death penalty trial, showing the shooting victims entering the church as well as Roof entering and, 52 minutes later, leaving and driving off in a black Hyundai Elantra. 
The last clip - from 25 minutes on - showed a shooting victim being removed from the church on a stretcher. 
Roof is charged with committing the killings with the intent of starting a race war. 
On the opening day of the 22-year-old’s death penalty trial, Assistant US Attorney Jay Richardson said the shooter sprayed his victims with more than 60 bullets on June 17, 2015. 
The defendant “chose to execute nine of those good and innocent men and women... because of a callous hatred for the colour of their skin,” the prosecutor charged. 
The white defendant’s “ racism , his violence, his assault on a house of worship won’t prevail in this courtroom,” said Richardson. 
A federal judge on Thursday denied a mistrial for Roof, as on Wednesday he was described as "evil" in testimony by a survivor of the deadly June 2015 attack. 
Lawyers for the 22-year-old argued eyewitness Felicia Sanders had offered prejudicial and improper opinion about what penalty he should face. 
During her testimony on Wednesday, the first day of Roof's trial, she said Roof sat through a Bible study meeting at Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Charleston and described him as "evil, evil as can be". Dylann Roof (Photo: Splash) 
The trial is taking place in the Charleston, South Carolina federal courthouse about a mile from the Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church where the killings took place. 
Authorities said he ranted racial slurs as he opened fire. 
Lawyers for Roof told jurors they dispute none of the evidence. (Photo: REUTERS) 
The US Justice Department has charged him with 33 federal criminal counts, including hate crimes resulting in death. 
The Justice Department is seeking the death penalty for Roof, who had offered to plead guilty in exchange for a sentence of life in prison. Like us on Facebook
